Yellowtail is my favorite fish, and I find that it is usually good even at mediocre sushi spots. But this one was actually pretty bad.  It was served room temperature and the texture tasted somewhat dry. This confirmed to me that the fish they use here is not the freshest and highest of quality.   In my opinion, they need to source better seafood and use less sauce/rice, or reduce their prices to match the quality.   +1 star for the ambiance +1 for the concept

Totally blown away by how delicious the food was. I'm giving this place a 5 star although is has some cons but the food and experience was that good.  Food choice: GO x2 (mind-blowingly Delicious)  Pros: The hand roll is made fresh right in front of you and served one at a time. It's so freaking delicious that you can't wait for the another one and then another one. The sushi chefs are super friendly and engaging.  Cons: The place is small but intimate. We came with a party of 8 and had to be split into 4 groups which was awkward to yell across the room to talk to a friend. The prices are also a bit out of hand but thankfully we came at the grand opening week and got a buy one get one free deal. Lastly, getting the food fresh out of the chef's hand was so unique but also means waiting around for 2 chefs to serve 20 people can be irritating.  Overall: I will be coming back and can't wait to try everything on the menu.

This place IS SOOOOO TASTY!!! Their lunch specials are fantastic and super affordable. It's a tiny lil place but man it's absolutely delicious and the employees are the sweetest. Kim, you're awesome!  We got the Hamachi Kama and duuuuuude so fresh! Finger lickin good :)

Came here around 11:15 AM on a weekday. The place was about 30% full. I ordered the \"GO\" because why not GO all out?  I don't think it's fair to compare sushi places in the US to the ones in Japan. The style that J Wata serves is very similar to the extremely popular Kazunori in Los Angeles. Don't expect sashimi inside your temaki. Also, the rice wasn't quite seasoned for sushi (don't expect akasu or komai, etc) but that's still okay. I think it could be borderline pretentious if someone puts that much effort into the rice for San Diego - given that the price range does not justify that much detail anyway - who cares!  The rule still stands similar to Japan and the US alike: eat as soon as possible when the chef hands it to you to keep the crispiness of the seaweed.  The temakis were good - I liked the lobster the most. I'd love to try to Uni+Ikura next time but I was pretty full from the meal. In the future, I'd prefer more handrolls with sashimi in them but I know that's pretty difficult to do given the prep time, etc.

Traditionally, temaki is made from leftovers and packed as a lunch, SO only in America will you see it offered in a restaurant and as an exotic, high-end dinner item. This 'bar' serves temaki strictly; seating is very limited. Typically, temaki is cone-shaped, but this restaurant and others have been going with the super hip 'rolled taco' version. Nori is held over a flame to warm and crisp it, then the rice is packed in with the protein on top. It is rolled by your chef and handed to you on the spot.   We came during the soft opening, so there wasn't much of a wait just before 6pm hit. Options at the time offered 3 set menus and some items a la carte. A little irked that the set menus included a little disclaimer of 'no sharing'. Who the hell are they to tell me how to eat MY food that I paid for!? Anyways, I went for *Shi* which included blue crab, negi yellowtail, spicy salmon, and bay scallop for $16.75. Sound a bit pricey? Indeed it is and you won't feel full after 4. I did mightily enjoyed the bay scallops the most though -- such a pop of freshness with the creamy mayo serving as a marinade. The others options were alright. Most seemed to rely heavily on the marinade. In that respect I did enjoy the *wagyu shabu* which I did have to order a la carte for a $7.75! This did not have a marinade and you were able to enjoy the lusciousness of the meat itself. The offering of wagyu was small and because of that I don't believe the $7.75 was a fair price. I wasn't a fan of the *negi toro* as it had a funny texture since it was a bit mashed up. I guess that's how it normally is so it does take some getting used to.   Nori was ever so slightly warm and it maybe offered a little crunch. Rice was ON POINT though. In addition to the freshness of the fish, the rice is definitely another important component and they make it right here; moist, but firm.   I am fairly certain the owner of RakiRaki will kill it though since there is nothing like this San Diego. I have a love-hate relationship with the man, but he offered a polished menu in a very well thought out and aesthetically pleasing restaurant. Congratulations on capitalizing on the next cool concept Junya Watanabe!

I mean, wow! First of all, great service and the was very friendly! I came for a BOGO promotion during their grand opening so there was a bit of a line but well worth it! I got the GO option which has Maine Lobster included, my fav! The soy was is double fermented (bomb) and the wasabi wasn't that fake stuff.  Not a huge spicy tuna fan but this wasn't the best spicy tuna I've ever had! It was FRESH! Must come here for some hand-rolls!  A bit on the smaller side, but he beat quality.

The food is very good. The service not that much, they are understaffed, and they are slow between hand rolls.  Also, the place does not close at 9. I have gotten there 4 times at 8:15 and they wouldn't take me, even with the place empty.

After the successes of RakiRaki and Pokiritto chef-owner Junya Watanabe has launched another restaurant concept - this time focusing on temaki (hand rolls). While there are plenty of sushi places that serve rolls or nigiri, not a lot of restaurants even offer temaki on the menu, much less exclusively serve them. Before this restaurant existed I could only get good handrolls from the famous Sugarfish as part of their set menu. At least now I don't have to go that far for temaki.  LOCATION: Convoy/Kearny Mesa in the same complex as the original Rakiraki and Pokiritto. As with any other restaurant in that area, parking situation's awful but at least this is my only negative critique about the restaurant.  VENUE: The restaurant's pretty small. A central sushi bar seats 22. Three to four chefs toast the nori in these special clay pots that contain the flame.   SERVICE: Friendly service. Hostess kept on asking us how our experience was.  The temaki is assembled right in front of you; they toast the nori, scoop the rice and fish, roll it and hand it to you. No need for chopsticks and oshibori is provided to wipe your hands before touching the sushi.  Our party chose from a set menu. My mom also included salmon sashimi ($7.25) as well as an additional negi yellowtail temaki ($4.75). Salmon sashimi was fresh. Didn't need so much sesame and soy sauce.  Set Menu - Go [5] ($21.75) There is a progression in the seafood that goes from the lightest to the heaviest. 1. Maine Lobster: the lightest temaki, as it should be. The lobster is already diluted with rice. They use a good quality lobster for this roll. 2. Spicy Toro: Salmon and tuna have both a spicy and a negi variation. The fish is pounded until the final product resembles cat food. There is enough hotness for it to be noticeable but not too much that it takes over the fish. 3. Negi Salmon: The negi in this case refers to green onion. In this case it lessens the fishy flavor. Since I'm not served the fatty parts of the fish I like #2 and #3 equally. 4. Bay Scallop: The bay scallop has mayonnaise in it and served warm. Final product is still quite delicious. 5. Blue Crab: Lots of good crab meat. Though I prefer Sugarfish's version, the blue crab is still fresh. Rice - Sushi-grade rice cooked in a small batch technique seasoned with 3 types of vinegar. Nori - Gold labeled seaweed sourced from Yamamotoyama  My parents and I came during their soft opening. We were pretty impressed with our experience in terms of quality of food and service. I could see this restaurant ending up in our regular rotation for places to go out, especially as good Japanese food is hard to find. Just bear the parking.

TIP: Do not come starving. You will leave disappointed and still hungry then make your way down to Caldron to fill yourself on the puffle like we did. I would consider this a snack or delicate meal.  Came here at 6:30pm during soft opening (6/10/) and the place had three others seated. Which was a bit awkward when literally everyone can hear your conversations due to the confined space. Especially the chef directly in front of you.  We were told each roll was crafted carefully and recommended to be eaten as soon as it was handed to you. That's exactly what we did. It was so good that I forgot to take photos! We ordered the 4 roll set menu and the scallop was my number one but they were all delicious.

I decided to treat my boyfriend to date night. We really enjoy sushi, and we haven't found our \"go to sushi spot\" since moving away from Long Beach. I wouldn't say J Wata hits the spot for us, but we did enjoy our dining experience while here.   Many sushi documentaries will explain the true passion that goes into sushi rice alone before discussing the fish. Every part of sushi making (nori, rice, fish, presentation...) is very methodical with intense attention to detail. At J Wata, I definitely got to taste of that kind of passion. Our sushi chef was very kind to make our hand rolls and explain his process, even talking about the fish and flavor notes to consider while eating. He educated us on eating sushi and his personal opinions, and was even throwing in some fish humor. It made the date more memorable than I even planned.   Food alone it was good, but having that kind of customer service was truly special. Regardless of the crappy parking lot, or maybe the fact that we were the first patrons of the night and it wasn't busy at all during our time, this place is simply dope.

My friend and I came at around 10:45am during the soft opening, and there wasn't a wait, plus plenty of parking in the notoriously difficult parking lot that the restaurant is located in. The restaurant is very small, with about twenty seats at a sushi counter top. In the middle, the chefs make the hand rolls, while people sit around the sushi bar.   I was somewhat skeptical of how good a hand roll could be, but to my surprise, the experience was very good. We went for the four-piece hand roll set that came with spicy salmon, scallops, yellowtail, and blue crab. My favorite of the four was yellowtail, since it was the sashimi in its pure form without any additional toppings or add ins. The scallop and blue crab rolls had fillings mixed with a mayonnaise type of sauce, and the spicy salmon was only mildly spicy.  The rice was soft and well seasoned, and the nori was crispy and warm. The cool fish contrasted well with the warm rice and nori, and I highly recommend eating it the second the chef hands it to you! The service was also very good, and the waitress was very attentive of our needs throughout the dining experience. I feel like this place will get busy really soon, so I would recommend coming early or before it opens to ensure a spot. Also, this restaurant isn't too good for large crowds, but it's perfect for a 2-3 people lunch date.

First things first, the price will probably give pause to many \"sushi\" lovers out there, but the small, intimate setting, welcoming d\u00e9cor and quality of product will keep you here.  Unfortunately here in Western culture sushi has become synonymous with rolls where the filling is wrapped inside out of the rice and cut. Based on sales and knowledge most people think nigiri or rolls, but the more true versions to eat are the maki and temaki rolls where the nori is on the outside with a proper proportion of fillings. All too often places overstuff rolls with rice and filling and they drown in sauces and toppings.   It's small, quiet, the customer service from both the chef and staff is amazing. I found the salmon sashimi was a great appetizer. The bay scallop was delicate. Something you'll notice is the premium ingredients. The rice in and of itself is great, the nori, properly toasted and crisp, the balance of rice to fish is perfect. The simplicity begets tradition.   I actually only came here because the lines next door were too long and I was parked illegally. They have some kinks to work out on the operations side, the marketing side and to convert an entire sushi people to unlearn a culture. It's ambitious to do something different, but I think to realty grab the hearts and minds of a demographic it has to be approachable, even if mildly to the wallet and maybe in not such a densely concentrated Asian food epicienter.  Update to come.

I've never had sushi of any kind that could compare to this place. I'm not an expert at all but I think anyone can tell how fresh and delicious it is.   Another thing I've noticed is that unlike most sushi places or even just restaurants in general - it may seem that three or four little temaki rolls won't be enough, and usually I'll walk out after sushi still somehow not feeling full after maybe 2-3 times as much.  The seafood here is so high quality that it's fulfilling in pretty small quantities. That's how good it is - it's real, pure food, not empty calories. I dunno but that was honestly a bit surprising to me, in a very good way of course. The appetizers are fantastic just like the temaki itself, of course.  It's not even that expensive, either! They have lunch specials and happy hour that go even cheaper without sacrificing any quality.  The chefs and servers are super nice, too, and I tend to see them casually chatting with customers as they're preparing food. The entire place has a really relaxing vibe and it's a perfect size.   The only real issue that I've had here is sometimes your order will get messed up - like one of the sets of temaki is meant to come with miso soup, which never did last time I went. And you have to make sure to mark everything correctly on the menu, another time my friend made a mistake but let the server know and still was served things she didn't mean to order.  None of that is a big issue at all, though. Everyone's so nice that I'm sure if you let them know they made a mistake they'd be sure to fix it - we just didn't bother because the food was so good we didn't even care.   So yeah, be sure you get what you're ordering but as long as you don't have any allergies, no matter what you get it's going to be delicious!

The whole experience was very underwhelming for me. Service was decent, I wasn't too happy that I had to ask my chef almost each time what handroll he was serving me. He would put it in my hand and walk away without saying anything. The idea of the nori being crispy sounds cool but parts of the nori would sometimes get stuck to the roof of my mouth. I really liked bay scallops and the blue crab hand rolls. I ordered the ikura and uni handroll and was NOT thrilled there was a mint (?) leaf in there! It overtook the flavor of the ikura and uni. Sigh :(  Glad I came here for the BOGO set offer. I don't think I'll be back. Handrolls were 3.5/5 stars good but not worth the size and price I'm paying for.

J Wata is the best sushi experience in San Diego by far. And I say experience and not restaurant, because coming here is quite an EXPERIENCE. Fresh made to order hand rolls, each individually crafted one by one and to be eaten right after handed to you. Cuts of some of the best seafood, atop perfectly cooked sushi rice, wrapped in freshly roasted seaweed.  Nothing complicated, just the impeccable quality of every ingredient that you sure can taste... even the soy sauce tastes amazing!  My favorite hand rolls are the scallop, Maine lobster, and negi toro! But you really can't go wrong with anything else they have!   They also have rotating appetizers and are always good as well. Be sure to check out what seasonal items they have when you go.   I also have to applaud how I receive consistently superior service here. All the sushi chefs are friendly and attentive, and they time the delivery of the rolls perfectly. Meaning your next hand roll comes a few minutes after you finish your previous one.  So do yourself a favor and try temaki style sushi at J Wata. You won't be disappointed!

Temaki is a concept that is new to me personally and honestly I enjoyed it.   We went for their grand opening event where it was buy one set menu, get one free which was a great deal!   We were seated right way when the place opened and were told about how their restaurant system works. After ordering our set menu, a chef would make our rolls and literally hand it to us one by one. They suggested we eat it right away to get the full effect of the roasted seaweed texture along with whatever filling we got.   We got the Go set menu which everything was pretty tasty. They use this sweet cream sauce to mix their fish in which complimented the crab, lobster, and scallops really well. I can imagine for the seafood connoisseurs though that they would feel like the cream over powered the actual meat but whatever.  The scallop to me was amazing. It's individual sweetness came through perfectly. The roasted seaweed wrap had a perfect crunch, something I've never experienced before. I guess the fact that it is roasted seconds before it is served to you really makes a difference.   The vibe I got from the restaurant was pretty cool. It was like modern and classic japanese decor infused together.   The whole meal experience was laid back and gave you the opportunity to relax and chat with whoever you're eating with. Don't expect a quick meal especially if there are a lot of people being served. The rolls came every few minutes which allowed me to savor each bit and get all the flavors.   I recommend coming here to give it a try and see if you like it!

Soft opening as of 7/7, so menu may change.  It's in the TightParKing Stripmall with RakiRaki.  Don't even try..  street park three blocks away and walk.  This place is all bar seating, one big U shape.  This makes the service personal and direct.  Friendly, fresh, and.. uniquely human.  The chef makes each handroll and hands it to you directly.  Pacing is up to you.  Very nice, and an easy place to dine solo or small parties.  I went with the midsize 4-roll combo.  No substitutions, but cheaper than the same rolls individually.  I'd call it lunch-sized..  you won't leave stuffed or starving.  These are open ended rolls, not the more common conical ones.  It's just rice and mixed fish ingredients, fresh, but without the greens and garnishes you might be expecting.  The flavors were good, but the hand roll format just doesn't floor me.  It's smaller than a sushi roll, and more seaweed-shell/nori than regular nigiri sushi.  The contents are good, but get a bit overshadowed in all that crunch and wrap, especially near the ends.  Best value on the menu was the hamachi sashimi, with jalapeno slices.  Very fresh thick slices, artfully arranged.  I would get that again.  Iced green tea was just a UCC can, not the fresh matcha you get at Ken's.  Wasabi was really weak, just vanished.  Value was a bit on the expensive side, especially compared to Pokeritto next door.  Service was very helpful and friendly, but this one-format menu might not be for everyone.  Five stars for service and novelty, but I think once was enough for me.

Came here for the BOGO grand opening event. The wait was around 25 min to get seated ( there are only around 25 or so seats- would be difficult for large parties).   Sushi is always on the expensive side... and this place is no exception, each hand roll is around $4-$5. And around 4 bites in size. It was nice they were having the BOGO otherwise this restaurant would be slightly out of my price range.   The service was quick, after ordering (shi and go sets) it took about 7 min for the chef to greet us and then another 3-4 min to get our roll. Their style is to serve one roll at a time for ultimate freshness. Between each roll there was a 3-4 min wait for the next.   My favorites were the lobster (very tender and the crunch of the seaweed added texture to the lobster) and the blue crab. The scallops had too much mayonnaise for me. I also enjoyed the spicy salmon.  The concept of this place is innovative and new so I feel like that will attract people even if the food is pricey and parking is somewhat difficult.   I would probably be back if they had another deal just on pricey side for me although the food is delicious and atmosphere is nice!

Very happy that San Diego now has a temaki bar! Ever since I went to Kazunori in LA I was hoping we would get one. They are still in their soft opening so the hours aren't set. They would be an ideal quick but delicious (and pricey) lunch, although parking might take too long to visit on a standard lunch break. Really, that parking lot is insane. And some times you can't even find anything 2 blocks on the street in any direction! Anyway...  The menu is simple and the quality of the food is good. The only problem I had is that the rolls kind of fell apart a bit. If you tried to turn it anything but vertical rice fell into the soy. If you held it vertical and took a bite, rice fell out the bottom. Maybe this is something they could fix in the future. My husband and I got 4 handrolls each and it was a $40 lunch without tip. The freshly crisped nori makes it so good though. I like it and hope to come back soon.

Went with a friend for the grand opening event. The atmosphere was pretty cool. I liked the art on the walls, music, and lighting. Service was ok.   We were seated in these lower seats in the dining area which were kind of secluded. It was  out of the way so we couldn't see the sushi chef making stuff and he would only briefly come over to give us our rolls. We could also see the trash behind the counter and the guy bussing dirty dishes was coming right in front of us.  The menu has sets of handrolls that go from 3, 4, or 5 rolls or vegetarian as well as a la carte rolls, appetizers, etc.   We got the \"go(\u4e94)\" set which had 5 handrolls: Salmon, lobster, scallop, spicy tuna, and blue crab. Which would have normally cost 21.75 per person but it was buy 1 set get 1 set free. Salmon and blue crab were good, but scallop and lobster had a lot of mayo and you could pretty much only taste the mayo. Spicy tuna was good, but for 21.75 I feel like you could go to pokkiritto and get something for cheaper. The portions are small and they do 1 roll at a time to pace you out, but we definitely left the restaurant hungry.   For the price and quality I definitely wouldn't go again, but its definitely something you can go to say you've gone.

Hand rolls are really good and the set menu options provide value.  I like the Go and Shi set.  The beer prices are whacked, $5.75 is overpriced, should be $4-5 at the most.  Services is good and there's never been a wait.

The wait is worth it. If you're a major sashimi fan and love handrolls this place is amazing. Handrolls come as you finish so that you get them fresh and enjoy the full flavors of the fish and toasted nori. The negi toro, scallops, blue crab and waygu are the best. Order a lot cuz you'll want more.   And chef Brian was so great to us.

Pretty comparable to Kazu Nori in LA!  I ordered the Shi (4) and got the Blue Crab, Negi Yellowtail, Spicy Salmon and Bay Scallop. I really enjoyed every hand roll on this set menu. I liked the fact that they added green onion to the yellowtail so it gave the roll a nice crunch. The Blue Crab and Bay Scallop had the perfect amount of mayo and it wasn't overly creamy!   Pricing: A little over $16 for 4 Parking: private lot + street parking

\"INCREDIBLE with Amazing Fish quality\"  THE BEST HAND-ROLL IN AMERICA.\u00a0 I am a Japanese. I have eaten sushi and sushi hand rolls everywhere in US. Haven't found anything like this!!  \u00a0 This place is just opened and the d\u00e9cor is modern contempo look with some Japanese themed Anime murals on the wall. I definitely dig the edgy look and minimalist feel. The wait staff was very courteous and attentive to my requests.  Now onto the food. Too keep things fresh, the chefs prepare each roll one-by-one, rather than sending them all out at once. The chefs toast seaweed each time with Hibachi (fire bowl) to make it extra crisp. \u00a0  I had salmon Sashimi, Blue Crab, Negi Yellowtail, Maine Lobster, Wagyu Shabu hand rolls .The price is very reasonable.\u00a0  My favorite one was Wagyu Shabu Roll. Shabu-shabu is one of the popular Japanese dishes. The chef boiled the thinly-sliced Wagyu beef in special hot broth to cook it and made hand-roll with it. It was absolutely delicious!!!  I am truly impressed with the quality level of ingredients of fish and meat here. I will definitely come back with my friends next week!!

Such a great experience to add to the Convoy area!  Freshly opened, this Temaki Bar really presents high quality ingredients and fresh hand rolls to guests. It's the perfect place for a date or a meaningful catch up with friends or family.  You are seated at a rectangular open bar with the chefs in the center. There's limited seating, so smaller parties definitely will work better - which also helps with the intimate attention you get from the chefs.  The walls have some amazing art to really add to the hip and classy atmosphere.  There are a few preset menus and individual rolls you can order - each with their own special umami to them!   I had the first set on the menu, Sashimi Appetizer, and a Wagyu Beef Hand Roll and was very impressed with the quality.  Highly recommend the savory Sashimi Appetizer! It meltsssssss into your taste buds!  Our servers were very nice and attentive and our chef who presented the hand rolls to us over the counter recommended we eat them quickly to enjoy the full quality and perfected temperatures.  A really great dining experience to try and live the good food life!

Kept the expectations really low walking in but wanted to see if toasted seaweed was really worth it. Seated in the observation booth and started out with the hamachi yellow tail sashimi. Fresh and fatty. The ponzu sauce and jalape\u00f1o over it was really good. Ended up getting the 4 course: blue crab, yellow tail, bay scallop and salmon. Honestly seeing them toast the seaweed and presenting it to you was a one of a kind experience. Not to sound like a effing snob but fuck that was delicious. The rice, with the freshness of the seafood and the crunch of the seaweed. The best hand rolls hands down. A beer, the sashimi and 4 rolls ran me $30. Came 40 minutes after open and not that crowded. Not sure how the wait would be during rush but still pretty good.   This is quality over quantity so I wouldn't expect to get full but who wants to feel like shit after eating high quality sushi.   My chef and another patron found out we were from the 562 as well so the experience of meeting familiar people was nice. Ask for James for your chef!

My girlfriend and I come here often for their happy hour. The main chef here is always friendly and provides us with a great experience that keeps us coming back. The happy hour can leave you with a much cheaper bill while still eating quality hand rolls. I recommend the negi toro hand roll.

The BEST hand rolls I've had. The combo of the cold fish and toasted nori is an epiphany, why hasn't anyone done this before? Also they make the rolls cylindrical vs cone shaped so you get an equal amount of fish and rice in each bite. Everything is so fresh, and the customer service is excellent. Make a reservation and try to go during the least busiest time. We went On a Friday at 1, the parking situation is very tough here, very small lot. They have good lunch specials but I would recommend the set menu.

Hubby and I really enjoyed their hand rolls, especially the bay scallops! We loved it so much we ended up ordering 3 of the Go set menu each consisting of 5 hand rolls!!! The only complaint I have is how they give you a small amount of their premiun soy sauce and a tiny ball of wasabi (see pic). Throughout the meal, I had to ask for 3 refills (which is a hassle) and yet it was not enough. Finding parking in this place is close to impossible, we're lucky enough to find street parking across the street. But they do have this 2 story parking structure across the street by Jasmine restaurant charging only $1 per hour.

Finally a Temaki Bar on convoy!  Short: Slightly pricy fancy sushi   Long: Coming from LA, one of my favorite things to do is to go get \"fancy\" sushi. J / Wata is a new hip place to go on Convoy if you want to experience that.   My favorite thing about this place is that they hand you one roll at a time; you'll get it fresh! I got the Shi which gave me crab, yellowtail, salmon and scallop. As you would expect, the fish was fresh and tasted good, not too chunky and overly chewy.   It is a bit pricy, and honestly value for sushi could be better elsewhere but when you're here you feel a sense of luxury.

I've been waiting for this place to open for a while. So fresh and so good.  Every single thing in the menu is top notch and won't disappoint.  The only problem I see is that price for lunch per person will be around $30 which is kinda of pricey even tough it's super fresh and tasty.

This place is phenomenal.. I found this spot on the Hot \u0026 new so I had to try it out for myself since I am a die hard sushi lover! Upon entering the server seats us \u0026 gives us a run down of how to order things. They have a small simple menu selection so this place is not somewhere to get SUPER full at without spending some moneeeyyy.   Price: honestly for the way the restaurant is set up \u0026 that each hand roll is made 1 at a time after you finish each one I knew it wouldn't be some cheap sushi spot price. My bf and I ordered the set of 5 rolls for $21 which is fair enough for the experience!  \u0026 also 2 ala carte Wagyu Shabu beef ones.  Food: lemme tell you..... each one I ate had so much flavor I was eating it so slow I didn't want it to go away. LOL the order we had was  1.Negi Salmon 2.Bay Scallop  3.Maine Lobster  4. Spicy Toro  5. Blue crab   And we paid an extra $8 for each of us to try the wagyu beef one since there was so many reviews that recommended it. Honestly I would never order a hand roll anywhere else ever again. I love how our chef explained to us their concept.  Made into cylinders instead of traditional cone shape- to ensure equal distribution for the rice and fish!   Made to order ( one at a time to you finish it) - so the rice stays warm, the seaweed stays nice and crisp and the fish doesn't harden up or get warm. All these tips were so helpful and the experience is something to try out! The wagyu beef one topped it all off.. so tender and juicy that I was really about to order another one. We will definitely be back. We didn't eat all day and this actually filled us up! We were at a good full.

I've been waiting to try a sushi joint that specializes in hand rolls and man, oh man was I completely satisfied!   We came on a Saturday and made reservations for 7:30 PM. We checked in with the hostesses who were extremely friendly and helpful. They also explain the menu/concept once your seated and promptly grab your drinks. The restaurant was full when we got in, but mind you, it is a small space. (I suggest making a reservation through Yelp!) The seating arrangement is in the form of a U-shaped bar so the chefs can easily make the rolls for you and the parties around you. The ambiance is like any other sushi restaurant and the sushi chefs try to communicate with you as much as they can, considering they are busy making rolls.  You can order sets here that come in 3, 4, or 5 rolls. There is an a la carte menu and a small appetizer menu as well. I ordered the Go set which comes with 5 rolls. My favorite is probably the Maine lobster roll and salmon. It was so delish! They toast the nori right in front of you which makes it perfectly crisp and helps with the chewiness when you take a bite. They give you one at a time and suggests that you eat it right away.   The prices are pretty fair. A set of 5 rolls cost $21 and a la carte prices are around $4-$8 depending on what you want. Overall, if I'm ever back in the area again I will definitely pay this place another visit!

My husband and I went yesterday for dinner after finding this place on Yelp. We had an incredible experience! The service was great, and all the food we tried was delicious. Our favorites were the waygu, toro and lobster. I like how they toast the seaweed to add a crunch when you eat. They also give you one hand roll at a time to make sure when you're eating it, it doesn't get soggy. We also had the sake sampler. They said they are partnering with a sake brewery and will have sake on tap soon as well as events. We will be back :)

A great place for a casual lunch with great food and service. Went there on a date and it was a great experience we both enjoyed it very much we felt comfortable the entire time and the food was fantastic.If you don't know what to order ask the chef to make something up, it worked out wonderfully for me.!

This place incredible. And is truly an experience.  What: One of a kind hand rolls that are served fresh, one-by-one. You east as you receive. This is not a quick, fast food place, and honestly, I like that about it. However, I would advise that this is not the best place to go if you're starving and need a lot of food right away. Where: A tiny space in Convoy next to Raki Raki Ramen and Tapioca Express. It's bar seating and not huge. Parking in this plaza is kind of a disaster, but we went on a Sunday afternoon and there wasn't a huge wait. Food: I had the Spicy Salmon, Hamachi Golden Ratio Tare, Blue Crab, Negi Toro, and Bay Scallop. This is also the order I would rank them in. The fish was all incredibly fresh and nori crips. The only downside I found was that the scallops are cold (I like hot food) and there was too much spicy mayo for me (this is a personal choice, my brother quite enjoyed it).    All in all, it was such a fun place and experience. I can't wait to go back.

Great experience! Went there alone and ordered a set and two other hand rolls. The salmon sashimi is fresh, and it came with soy sauce already brushed on the fish (which I really like). The uni roll and blue crab roll are the best I've tried.
First time dining here. Really enjoyed the freshness  of the fish and the toasted nori!

Hand roll sushi bar in San Diego.  It's done in the same vein as Kazunori in LA.  Executed at a fairly high level.  Premium ingredients, crisp seaweed, and fairly consistent ratios of rice and proteins.  My favorite is the negi salmon.  I order multiples every time I go.  Bay scallop, blue crab, and lobster hand rolls high quality as well.  Spicy rolls are good.

I was in town for a quick day business trip and decided to stop in for dinner. This place looks modern from the outside with the wood trim. Inside, the mural reminds me of \"Kill Bill\" for some reason.   Nice and cozy and we had the counter seats. I was driving all day so I worked up an appetite. You just fill out the menu card and the roll starts coming on. Started off with some hand rolls and sashimi which was amazing. The fish tastes really fresh and rice just right.   I was still hungry so ordered the Waygu roll. Totally amazing and melts in your mouth good! The flavor was just something to be experienced. I am glad my friend recomended this place. Would definitely come back next time in town.

Ok this place is REALLY good.  It's a one of a kind experience, the rolls are served one by one and the chef advises you to eat it right away, as it is the best way to enjoy the flavor.  This place serves Temaki rolls, so don't expect your regular california roll or anything along that line. The pictures listed in here definitely do not make justice to the flavor of the rolls. Believe me when I say I'll definitely be coming back.  The seaweed is toasted, so eating it right away gives you a crunchy taste.. If you wait too long, the seaweed looses its crunchiness. I got a 4 pc set menu, and even though at first I thought it was not gonna be enough food, I was completely satisfied!
They were extremely accommodating of my dietary needs. In fact, they asked about them before we even ordered. The temaki was outstanding. Will be back again soon!

WOW. I didn't realize what I was missing out on until I ate the hand rolls here.   The seaweed is freshly toasted...roasted...? It gives it this nice crunch and really brings out the flavor of the seaweed. From looking at the pictures, I thought these rolls looked pretty basic, but I was so wrong. They're full of flavor and pleasant textures. It's made fresh before your eyes and really brings in that excitement when you know you're moments away from getting your next mouth-watering hand roll. Make sure you take that first bite right away to know what I mean when I rave about the seaweed!   I tried their \"Go\" set which includes 5 hand rolls so that I can try a variety of rolls for a better deal. I was pleasantly stuffed by the end of it. Next time I'll go a la carte for rolls that I really want (uni, ikura, uni+ikura, wagyu, unagi) that may not be included in their set menu.   Overall great experience sitting at the bar with my S/O. The chefs and staff were very friendly, needless to say I'll be back over and over again!

You walk in and you immediately feel as though you belong to some sort of secret club. But you won't find a slither of arrogance. We were seated, our orders were taken, and ten minutes later we had a beautiful roll directly put in our hand. Fresh fish...simplicity... I'll take it... Thank you for the fantastic experience, kindness and welcoming spirits.

3.43 stars. Its decent, but not for enough that I want to round up to 4 stars. I think if you've had KazuNori in LA before, this experience will fall short. But if you haven't, it should be fine. The fish is fresh enough and the seaweed is toasted, which is unique. The rolls aren't very filling though and the wait time is a little ridiculous. The second time I went, it was an hour wait. Totally not worth it, so I went around the corner for a sushi burrito instead. Twice as filling, half the price, and zero wait. I'd wait maybe 25 minutes for this place tops. Even then, I don't think I'd pay the $20 some dollars for the set menus. It's missing something, I just can't place it.

My family wanted to go here while they were visiting me a few weeks ago because there aren't any good hand roll bars in OC. We ordered the Go set menu as well as the waygu shabu and uni hand rolls. Everything was delicious and fresh. They even have real wasabi which is a major plus!   Parking can kind of be crazy in this plaza like many places on Convoy.
This place is amazing! I just wish the pricing was a little cheaper! I feel like more people would go as well! I'm still hungry after!

I'm definitely one that likes a lot of choices but the simplicity of their menu does not take away from the delicious quality of their food. It's not your typical sushi spot with a ton of different rolls and as I'm sure you know by now, they specialize in Temaki aka hand rolls. I still enjoy crazy over the top rolls from time to time but I feel like with sushi, the simpler the better so that you can really taste and appreciate the ingredients. You can order in \"sets\" or a la carte depending on whatever suits your palate. Each handroll is made to order and they make one at a time for you, which are meant to be enjoyed RIGHT AWAY. It's really cool because they toast up your seaweed so it has that roasted flavor and gets crispy and roll them up as you go. I got the Go set which came with: blue crab, spicy toro, negi salmon, bay scallop \u0026 Maine lobster (although not in that order.) All of them were really good but blue crab was my absolute favorite. I had a bite of the unagi too which had a big piece of flavorful unagi. We also shared the hamachi sashimi in which you could also taste the freshness and quality just like everything else. My onlyyy gripe is that the hand rolls are a little small and while I left at a satisfied full (meaning I still had room for Somi Somi after haha) the guys were still hungry. Super cool experience though and will definitely be recommending them to all my friends!
An amazing experience highlighted by phenomenal fresh food, prepared in a traditional setting and manner that give you a intimate experience with this fun personal staff

I have been here 3x.   Decent sushi bar can do some work in improving service. Timing of when items are served are off - this is a casual bar style restaurant so timing should be the most important aspect of service outside of food.  I know the employees try very hard but if I got my hand rolls before my salad, then there's a problem. Overall, food tastes fine - I like that they warm their rice but flavors (especially rice) can be slightly more pronounced and proportions can be done better - negi to toro ratio was off (needs a bit more negi to balance evenly).   Lighting can be improved to make the dinner experience less \"cafeteria\". Additional hand roll chefs would help, too. Really want this place to do well since the staff is friendly but management can look into the above issues to make the improvements that will really make this place shine.

Came in for their grand opening which they offered a BOGO deal! It was a very unique dining experience. Upon arriving, our waiter sat us and explained how the dining experienced worked. They give you a order menu in which you check what you would like to order and then they give it to the chef. My boyfriend and I both ordered the \"GO\" set which includes 5 handrolls. ( Maine lobster, spicy tuna, bay scallops, negi salmon, blue crab). The Maine lobster and bay scallops were my favorite. The spicy tuna and negi salmon were pretty mediocre and the blue crab had to be my least favorite. Tasted straight up like mayo. They also had a premium soy sauce but recommended to dip only alittle so it wouldn't overpower the taste of the handroll.  I love how they flame roast the nori which gives it a crispy texture. You get one handroll at a time, so once you've got your handroll, the chef is making another handroll for another customer. There were about 25 seats in the restaurant with 2 chefs on each side of the bar. The total time it took from start to finish was about 45mins for 5 handrolls. Overall, the experience was great, the staff was nice and attentive. It's a little pricey for everyday eat, but definitely nice for an occasion or once in awhile! Also parking sucks to be sure to come early.

Wow. Had an amazing meal with amazing service. Ian, our waiter, was so attentive and very knowledgeable about the menu. He recommended some of my FAVORITES including the hamachi hand roll, waygu hand roll, and soft shell crab hand roll. Not to mention, we tried the semi dry sake and it was bomb! Would definitely recommend for a unique experience and great vibes. Thanks Ian!!

For everyone wondering if this place is as good as Kazunori in LA - it is. Maybe even a little better.  I got the \"Shi\" set which comes with 4 hand rolls, and I added a Negi Toro. Five rolls had me satisfied, but I got one more Blue Crab roll and I was STUFFED. The quality of their seafood is on point, but what really makes it is the seaweed and the rice. Make sure you bite into the hand roll right away to fully experience the extremely crisp nori!  On top of their hand rolls, this place makes sure their ginger and wasabi is high quality, too. The wasabi isn't your typical wasabi out of the tube. It has actual flavor, depth, and texture. I loved it so much I got extra!  I'm glad I've found my favorite place for hand rolls in San Diego. The delicious hand rolls and friendly customer service will keep me coming back for sure.

This was such a nice place! A co-worker and I went on the Friday before the Grand Opening and I tried the Go (5). This experience was really interesting because there is a chef in the center of the restaurant making your rolls as you eat them. They hand them directly into your hands and makes them on the spot! My favorite roll was the Bay Scallop, which was so fresh with the warm sushi rice and mixed in some kind of mayo sauce. Every roll is light and refreshing. I would say 5 was just enough to feel satisfied and not bloated.   The menu is set and be careful if you have seafood allergies. The restaurant is a bit small and has maybe about 15-20 seats around in a bar setting!

I have been coming to this place way too much. I am a bit obsessed with it though.  I love the simplicity of J Wata. They do strictly hand rolls with 1 or 2 sashimi specials.   I have eaten almost every single type here. If you are new, try one of their pre set menus. They give you a great variety and pricing is slightly better than just ordering a la carte.   My favorites are: Blue Crab Spicy Toro Negi Salmon  The chef will hand you each roll one by one with the intention of you eating it right away to preserve the crispness of the nori with each bite. They only have counter seating for about 20ish people, so it may be difficult to come with a big group or with small children. I have taken my 3 year old daughter here and she does well as she loves sushi/sashimi.   A great addition to SD food scene as it is unique. Parking is a nightmare but worth it. I come here and then head over to Cauldron for dessert.

This is a fantastic sushi bar. The chic decor and comfortable seats greet patrons as they enter, and the menu provides options for dedicated sushi diners as well as vegetarian friends. The wait staff takes orders and attentively serves throughout the meal. The chefs present hand rolls one by one, all carefully prepared and deliciously flavored. Each roll has a uniquely wonderful taste that is elevated by its warm rice and flame-crisped nori. To eat here is to know delicious sushi.

I got 2 Negri Salmon and a Negri Toro..each made and handed to me one at a time.. wow.. these are way yummier than any other place.. they sear the nori (seaweed) so it's crisp.. then they create the perfect size roll for easy eating. The fish was divine and the sushi rice perfection..this exceeded my expectations. I equate it to eating in Italy where they use very few but quite exceptional ingredients. The service was spot on as well.. this is a perfect place to start with a lil something as u wait for your table at Raki Raki Ramen

Amazing. The quality is outstanding. They really take take the time to ensure that the food is up to the highest standards. So much so, that they won't make the hand rolls to go since it wouldn't taste as good straight from the chef. I respect that. Too many restaurants are out to make a profit from crappy food. I'm thrilled that J Wata elevates their food to the next level. I'll be back time and again!

The concept behind this 24-seat bar are premium handrolls! The menu is small but that is because each handroll is made right in front of you and served personally by the chef. The chef waits until you have finished eating your current roll before making the next one. My husband and I were able to dine in on one of the Grand Opening weekends.  They have been opened for about a month and the word has gotten out.  We came right at 11 am and had no problem getting a seat. When we left 55 minutes later, there was a line.  All of the staff we interacted with were very friendly, made us feel welcome and answered any questions I had. One novelty of this place is that they roast each seaweed on top of a charcoal open flame to get it toasty. You can hear the crunch when you take a bite. I really enjoyed the texture of the nori! They give you a disposable wet towel to wipe your hands with when you sit down. Even though there were chopsticks available, I just used my hands! The usual cone-shaped hand rolls hold everything at the bottom, but these were open ended rolls, so if you are prone to being clumsy like me, you had to be careful because the filling easily came out once you were near the end of the roll.  We chose the Go set that came with 5 rolls.  There are no substitutions and no splitting plates.The rolls are about five inches long packed with simple ingredients.We started with the Maine Lobster roll. It was packed with a lot of lobster meat! Delicious! The next roll was the Spicy Tuna roll. It was great, but we're used to eating this sushi so it didn't make that big of an impression. The third roll was a Bay Scallop roll. This was one of my favorites! You can taste the freshness of the seafood and the mayo ratio was just right! The fourth roll was a Negi Salmon roll.   Again, one of our regular sushi rolls. It was also good. The last roll was the Blue Crab roll.  It was heavenly! The sweetness of the crab melted in my mouth! This was very yummy. One might think four or five rolls doesn't make for a filling meal, but when you take the time to savor each one and patiently wait for the next while having good conversation, I was satisfied! This also leaves some room for dessert. The receipt offered a 15% off a same day purchase at the Angels and Hearts creperie next door. Yogurt World and the newly opened Cauldron are a few doors down as well.  The atmosphere is like an open exhibition kitchen with interesting art on the walls.  Initially there was only one Chef working while Chef Brian was still prepping. But once the place filled up,  Chef Brian jumped in to start filling the orders. I'm glad too because I wanted some \"sushi chef\" talk and got the chance to banter with Chef Brian. That's part of the sushi bar experience, right? If you like seafood, I think you will enjoy this place. I have never ordered a lobster, scallops or blue crab roll at other places because of the price, but this set of five rolls was $21.75 and worth it. Ok, I mainly gave some positives right? So here's some negatives: -Parking in this strip mall can be like the Hunger Games so be prepared! I don't really count this against the restaurant though.  Maybe Chef Watanabe can invest in a parking garage nearby since he owns a lot of the places? -The water came with no ice.  I like ice. We had to request for some ice when it came time to refill. But again, our server was very nice (and nice-looking too, hehehe).  -Here's the one thing that was off-putting. The Chefs are gloved up making the rolls but then they are also touching tablets with the same hands checking on what to make next.  Does this only bother me thinking about yucky germs being spread? Not sure how to fix that.  Chef Brian was using his pinky finger to swipe on his device, but I'm certain his pinky also touches the mound of rice whenever he grabs some for his next roll and so on. Whatever. I guess I've seen worse. Overall for the taste, friendly staff and concept, 4 stars!

Ordered the Hamachi Kama appetizer and received it well after we were done with our food. Don't call something that takes 45 minutes to make an appetizer especially if you are going to serve it to your customers after they are done with their food, that ultimately makes it a dessert!

Overall experience is just okie. Coming from LA we are very blessed to have Kazu Nori. Therefore when compared I would still pick Kazu Nori.   Freshness of the fish is very good. However I think the lobster and the crab marination could be changed. I can definitely taste the wateriness residue from the protein. Maybe they need to squeeze out the excess water before mixing their mayo and seasoning.   I did not like the part where we can not take out the spicy option from the set menu. Some people may prefer non spicy.   Also the order of how the fish is presented is very random. I think it would be better if they presented the fish according to light to heavy. I started with lobster which I think messes up the taste palette. So maybe start with toro, salmon, scallops, crab, lobster.   They heated the seaweed which was interesting. I would definitely give it another chance granted it just opened. And there is nothing like this in SD.   If ever the chef/owner can try Kazu Nori in LA. I would definitely recommend so they can get some inspiration.

Actual rating: ** 3.5 stars  (since yelp doesn't allow half stars)  Having tried Kazunori in LA and be an avid fanatic of the place, I was curious of J Wata ever since I caught wind of it on Eater. Still on their soft opening, there are a handful of things they can still improve on and hopefully they will. Of course, I have a great feeling that J Wata will constantly be compared to Kazunori for those who have had the pleasure of experiencing both. That being said, the food and service were quite alright given that they are still getting things situated. I still have to say my review greatly compares my experience at J Wata against Kazunori, glossing over some aspects and concentrating on others.  Layout: The layout of both eateries are the same. Limited seats surrounding the chefs. I want to say that the number available seats are similar, but the number of chefs serving are lesser at J Wata. The art on the walls was definitely cool though, depicting a Japanese style anime biker gang with one side having a red bike - reminding me greatly of Akira.  Service:  If memory serves me right, a huge difference is that there are more chefs serving you at Kazunori. I recall having to wait maybe a minute or two tops after finishing my handroll to receive another at Kazunori even when it was jam packed. During my visit to J Wata, the place was half full and had two chefs working the booths. The chefs were working as best they could, but could not keep up with how fast a person might take to eat their roll. I definitely waited a bit after finishing each one. I would hope and suggest that a third chef is brought in once the soft opening is over with.   I do have to point out that the order tracking devices they were using were malfunctioning a bit so that could have added to the delay. As for the chef himself and the wait staff, they were all quite polite and relatively attentive. Nothing bad to say there.   Price: I was a little disappointed in this category. Kazunori definitely has this point beat as the hand rolls there are noticeably cheaper by set and per roll. As it stands, the pricing at J Wata makes me hesitate returning... at least not as much as I visit Kazunori.   Food:  Now here is the part I have to emphasize that I am REALLY comparing this place to Kazunori. It's hard to ignore that J Wata probably takes after Kazunori. The ordering system is the same where you can order hand rolls a-la-carte or as a set. I got a set and ordered something on the side.   The nori is toasted per roll in order to have them crisp and break apart when you bite into it. Personally, I feel like this wasn't executed perfectly because the center of the nori of each roll I had was chewy, causing the filling (fish and rice) to fall out on the other end. The ends were fine but the center was the problematic point. Kazunori has this down and I don't recall ever having to struggle on any of my visits.  The rice was good, standardly seasoned as any other sushi restaurant. Even so, there is a stark difference as Kazunori and the Nozawa shops distinctly season their rice. I could taste the difference between the rolls of J Wata and Kazunori. You'd have to try Kazunori or Nozawa to know what I am referring to. By preference, I prefer Kazunori's seasoning more because it allowed me to enjoy the roll without using soy sauce.  The fish was definitely fresh. Nothing was fishy so I very much enjoyed that. I ordered the 4 set, which included  blue crab, negi yellowtail, spicy salmon, and bay scallops. They were all good and seasoned decently, but I can't say they were great or amazing. Again by preference, I feel that Kazunori wins out again in this category. Both places, the fish was was unmistakably fresh, but Kazunori just adds something else more to the fish to amplify the flavor. My favorite at Kazunori, the blue crab, was a bit more muted at J Wata. For every roll following it, the same sentiment was had.  Overall, J Wata is not a bad place. Despite me making it sound like they are a mess, it's good. It's just that, in my opinion, it has very big shoes to fill if they are actually modeling themselves after Kazunori. There's good reason that Kazunori and Nozawa constantly has lines out the door. I just truly hope that J Wata works it out or establishes itself to be a real contender in the future once the dust has settled.

Best Temaki I've had. The fish was fresh, the seaweed was warm \u0026 not dry, the rice was warm \u0026 not dry. Highly recommend! I tried the negi salmon, spicy salmon, unagi (eel) my personal favorite, yellowtail, Maine lobster, scallops, spicy tuna \u0026 all were amazing!   I'd only come here solo or with 1 other person, definitely not good for children.  The place is super small \u0026 only seats a handful around 1 entire table/bar in the whole place. Food comes out 1 item you order at a time, it's nice to pace yourself \u0026 really enjoy it.

This is already a hot spot and it hasn't even officially opened yet.  I went with a few foodie friends and they all said this is the best they've had. From the raw wasabi to the rolls ...and that yellowtail collar! A must.

Straight out of swanky harajuku!  The space is absolutely stunning.  With the chefs hand rolling each order in the center its a culinary performance that pleases the eyes and appetite.  The edgy murals remind me of the street scenes of young rebels on the Tokyo streets.  As Unapologetically irreverent as Japan generally is apologetically reverent.  The urban vibe combined with the clean lines of this Temaki bar is also reflected in the food.   Leave your past experiences with the typical handroll at the door.   The jwata handroll is wrapped In sumptuous Nori hand warmed on an open flame in front of you.  Yes, hand - warmed - on an open flame !  The Sushi rice is light , fluffy , and delicately seasoned.  The fish is supple, rich , and infused with some kind of essential sauces ?  What can be better ?  The Wagyu beef swish, swished Shabu Shabu style.  What can I say.  Arigato!!

The sushi chefs are just fantastic, service is excellent. Cool look inside the restaurant. I couldn't ask for a better experience. The artistry and quality of the ingredients are both top-notch. I have celiac disease and they easily accommodated my needs.  I am already looking forward to going back.

Basically all they serve is hand rolls. They're not bad but the ambience is weird and doesn't feel authentic watching this young kid making it in front of me. Overall awkward service with not much authenticity.

I've been to a place called KazuNori in LA with the same concept...  just hand rolls so to my surprise they had open a place in SD with the same concept I wanted to try right away! My friend and I visited during their soft opening and luckily after the lunch rush hour. The rolls were delicious. The fish was super fresh and the rice was tasty! I will definitely be back and will the spread the word!

It was my first night in SD and my plan was to just jump between a bunch of different restaurants--J Wata being the very first. On my flight out of SD, though all the restaurants I had hopped around to were great, J Wata just stayed on my mind and I would definitely go back to try everything on the menu.   Reading other reviews, you'll quickly find out the format of this place: you select what you want on a piece, pass it to a server, and the server will pass it to the chef (who is right in front of you). He'll make each roll in your order one by one, meticulously toasting the seaweed over an small, open flame while parsing through what you and everyone else has ordered on a tablet. Once the seaweed is toasted and he assembles the hand roll, he'll pass it directly to your hands for you to consume.  I only had a few hand rolls and a miso soup but every single bite I had was so amazing. I wasn't even able to take any pictures because waiting any longer than 30 seconds made the nori less and less crisp and you really have to have the roll go from the chef right to your mouth. The rice was great and the seafood was incredibly fresh.  Another great thing about this format is that, as a guest, you do not have to wait long before you get your first bite. The chef rotates making rolls between guests so everyone is satisfied. In some sort of way, it's good that you have to wait because you spread out your experience and are able to enjoy eat bite on its own, letting the flavors in your mouth truly sink in before haphazardly moving onto your next piece.  My only issue is that each roll is fairly expensive--about $4-7 each from what I remember--but it is really worth it and I would not mind splurging here once in a while if I was a local.

Sad to say I had to lower the score from five stars to two stars because today I tried to eat lunch at J Wata but there was only one sushi chef serving and preparing for everyone at the bar and it was busy, which meant extremely slow service, a long wait in between cones, and on a weekday at lunch peek hour I just didn't have the time to wait for their extremely slow pace. The other day when I reviewed with five stars, the chef told me they were struggling to bring clients in, and they didn't know until when they would remain open. My question is: how do you expect to keep your customers if you cannot provide for them a good and quick lunch service on a busy weekday? If you cannot have two sushi chefs when it is most busy, then you are hurting your own business, no matter how delicious your food is. I for one will not return to J Wata ever again on a weekday, total waste of my time!   J Wata has the freshest and most delicious Temakis (cones) EVER! If you love sushi and have not been here you have yet to try the best of the best. Amazing quality of products, fantastic service, pure deliciousness. I am a fan! If I lived closer I would eat here every other day. I so wish they would open in North County! J Wata is the best!

My friend and I both ordered the GO plus their Hamachi special. We both agreed that they should've served the items in reverse order because it started off sooo great and then gradually declined in flavor with each new roll.   The lobster roll was the best. Spicy tuna was our 2nd favorite. The salmon was good but on the bland side. The bay scallops and blue crab had too much mayonnaise. It actually made the crab taste like canned tuna and I couldn't even taste the scallops. Lastly, the special Hamachi roll with diced raw jalape\u00f1os was disappointing. We love jalape\u00f1os and spicy food, but these jalape\u00f1os were tasteless. There was no spice or even jalape\u00f1o flavor. Even the crunch of these jalape\u00f1os didn't seem to compliment the roll. They were just in the way so I ended up scraping most of it out of mine. I would've ordered another lobster roll, but at $7+ for a la cart, I decided to just get the check.   The super cool wall murals were painted by an artist from LA. One of the servers told me the artist's name, but I forgot.   Service was excellent and the price would've been fine had all the rolls tasted consistently good. Overall, we'd go back to try the other rolls but we're not in a hurry to.

such a great place. not for the non experienced i would fairly say. great rolls. great prices. friendly staff. finally a place that gets it. I had my Bday dinner here tonight with my wife. such a great experience. fight that parking and get eating

Its an unique and pleasant dining experience. It definitely is on the pricey side, which is why I am glad I was able to use the BOGO deal they had for their grand opening. The staff were attentive and the chef was able to deliver each hand roll at a good pace. I like the pacing since it gives us time to enjoy and savor the taste in each and every bite. Enjoyable but probably not a place that will fill you up.

I'm writing this review as I finish the last bite of my Hamachi Golden-ratio Tare.   The hand rolls here are incredible. So fresh tasting. I got the negi yellowtail, Hamachi golden ratio tare (as stated above), the uni, and the wagyu shabu. I have to say the uni was so clean and wasn't extremely briney. The wagyu also melted in your mouth. I highly recommend you eat the rolls immediately as they are handed to you, or you won't be able enjoy the full experience of the roll. They also toast the nori so that adds another incredible element to the roll. I can really appreciate the simplicity of the hand rolls as it allows the fish or meat being served to really shine. I have been searching for a truly authentic Japanese sushi experience since we moved here in January and I've finally found it! I can't stand those rolls drowning in sauce and inauthentic sushi ingredients. Thank you all for an amazing dining experience! I definitely will be back!

I went here with a few friends the other night. Being a vegetarian, I wasn't too sure what to expect but did see that they had a few options on the menu. The restaurant is very stylish and all seating is bar style. The staff is extremely attentive and each seat comes ready with wasabi and fresh ginger. The menu is simple, high-quality hand rolls. Ideally, one would order one of three set menus that vary in size from 3 to 5 hand rolls. I ordered a la carte since I was getting the vegetarian options.   I ordered three hand rolls: mayo avocado, shiitake mushroom, and a Japanese root vegetable one (the name I cannot recall) with shisho. All are made to order, and one at a time. They were all delicious. The manager or owner also said I hard to try the last vegetarian option which was a fresh ginger and shisho hand roll, it was very refreshing and ON THE HOUSE.   My friends ordered the 3 or 4 temaki hand roll sets and they loved them.   Overall, a nice, unique place that is taking the time to do simple food extremely well.   Definitely would go back here.
Great new spot! The contrast of flavored from the sticky rice, fish, and fresh crunchy nori. My favorites: hamachi (yellowtail), and blue crab

The concept is promising but the food and service is lackluster. We came in on a Sunday afternoon with only 3 other patrons in the restaurant. The server took our initial order but forgot our water so we had to remind her. We received our appetizers along with the first hand roll within a reasonable amount of time. We ordered a la carte in small orders (1 or 2 temaki at a time). Our second order took much longer than it should have because the chef and other staff were talking around a laptop near the front door for at least 15 minutes. Also, for our final order, we received only 1 of the 2 temaki's so we had to remind the chef. The sushi rice and toasted seaweed were flavorful and enjoyable, but the fish was average, and served in very small portions. The wagyu beef roll was very disappointing; it was 2 small slices of wagyu beef with rice which was very plain tasting. Even at the happy hour price it's not a good deal. The appetizers were also very small portions. At best, this place is suited for happy hour; but even then you may leave feeling unsatisfied and craving bigger portions of sushi.

This place used to be amazing.  I went today for lunch and half the items weren't available.  Seems to me that if they aren't going out of business they would have more supply.  Disappointing because the food was really good.

J Wata is a refreshingly authentic Temaki experience, the quality of the fish was incredible and the atmosphere was intimate and fun. Ian was an incredibly knowledgeable and delightful server who made some really helpful recommendations and offered great insight, he pointed us in the direction of the soft shell crab roll which ended up being the highlight of the evening. You know it was a great experience when you start planning your next visit as you walk out of the restaurant. Also special shout out to the sake menu (our boy ian helped us pick the best bottle) and the salmon tower appetizer, this place is legit.

Disclaimer: I LOVE handrolls so couldn't wait to try this place. The fish is indeed fresh, and the warmed/toasted nori is a very nice touch. However I felt the value was lacking for what you get. Limiting factors include: a predominately handroll menu so maybe not enough a selection to sustain a business in this area. They also don't do to go orders so you cannot share the goodness with anyone unless they actually come to the joint. The parking is the worst too, so that alone almost makes it not worth coming back to.

Nothing spectacular about this place. My boyfriend and I LOVE sushi so we definitely wanted to check out this restaurant. The price is pretty expensive for what it is. We got a course of 6 maki rolls for almost $30 per course. We only received 5 of the rolls and asked where the 6th one was. The chef swore he gave us all of them but we never received the toro roll. He gave it to us in the end and we definitely have not had it. He confused the salmon roll he gave us for the toro. The fact that he made us feel pretty bad for reminding him totally threw me off. It's a shame because the maki was pretty fresh and delicious. However, I'm definitely not coming back.

New cool spot on Convoy by the owners of Pokirrito. I must say its basically a sugarfish ( LA Sushi Spot) but in San Diego. The customer service is fantastic but the hand rolls are good. Nothing was RIDICULOUS AMAZING. It was just good. Its very traditional Japanese, not what we are used to in San Diego; the spicy creamy sauces etc. I can come back but definitely a bigger fan of Hane.

Delicious and hip. The quality of the rolls is outstanding. They put a great deal of effort into making each roll by hand and make sure it comes out perfect each time. The service was outstanding too, whenever we needed anything they were able to provide it quickly. I was very surprised of the price for the quality, you're definitely getting your money's worth here.   I recommend coming to try it out. This is going to become a very popular place in San Diego.
Food and service were good. Taking out 2stars because of over priced. I have been there twice but not sure if I would go there again.

I tried this place for dinner while visiting San Diego from Orange County last week. Great food. Fun vibe. Friendly staff. The rolls are handmade and delicious. Overall, I loved my first visit to J Wata. It will definitely be on my go-to list anytime I'm in San Diego.

Awesome place. My girlfriend has celiac's and has to do gluten-free (GF). They were very, very attentive to that and made sure to highlight the items in the menu that were gluten free. They also have gluten free soy sauce.  The hand rolls were EXCELLENT. I loved the negi salmon, bay scallops, and the Maine lobster. The blue crab hand roll was extremely fresh and amazing. The seaweed was wonderfully crispy, the rice was good, and the fish was fresh.  This was their soft opening so I don't know what it will be like after the grand opening. I would suggest a more  sake selection, but that's my only complaint. I loved the casual bar setting, fast service, and great service.  Update: They had a highlighted menu up front for the servers to reference so they knew what was gluten free. The manager remembered my girlfriend and I from our last visit and he told us about some of the recipe changes they made, including changing the mayo they use so the hand rolls (blue crab, Maine lobster, bay scallop) were GF now. Awesome that they were willing to make that accommodation we appreciated that they remembered us.
This place is awesome. Quality ingredients, very friendly and attentive staff. We love James! He is always so welcoming and helpful!

Cannot say enough good things about my first experience dining here. All of the food was extremely fresh and flavorful. The staff were attentive and friendly. The time spaced out between each handroll is perfect enough to thoroughly enjoy each different one. My personal favorite was the bay scallop. Highly recommend coming for both the food and experience!!

Came in for J Wata's soft opening, and I was delighted by what a unique dining experience it is! I was only used to eating temaki in the cone shape. The chef, James, was really friendly and explained that the round/cylinder shape allows for better distribution of ingredients. The fish was very tender and flavorful, and the hand rolls felt delicately and carefully put together.   It's pricey for everyday dining, but definitely an experience to see the nori flame-roasted and to taste hand rolls straight from the chefs. I would totally come again for a special occasion or when I want to impress someone with how refined my tastes are.

Awesome and fun! This is my first time getting the hand roll experience at the bar. I've been to plenty of sushi bars and this felt very similar! It is currently still in soft opening, so the menu suggestion is pretty limited. They have different \"sets\" available which makes it easy to choose if you want 3, 4, or 5 rolls. I'm a picky eater so I have been ordering hand rolls a la carte, which costs more. Oops!   Spicy Toro 10/10 - Yum! Its so buttery and melts in your mouth.  Spicy Tuna 9/10 - Still good, but prefer the fatty tuna!  Blue Crab 8/10 - Its very good but I just don't love crab all that much. This hand roll is in most of the set menus.   They toast the seaweed so its warm, the fish inside is chilled. Eat it fast, after taking a quick picture of course.   Overall its a very simple place. There's hand rolls, a couple of sashimi plates, and that's about it. I love that about it. Good atmosphere. In and out kinda of place. Actually that would depend. If there's only one chef and more packed, the wait between rolls may take a while. I've been where I was stuffing the hand rolls because there was no other customers and also a little bit too long of a wait between.   Can't wait to see grand opening menu!

An amazing and unique dining experience in San Diego. The chef hands you each roll perfectly timed (very similar to KazuNori in LA but a more comfy experience). It's an exceptionally efficient process that amazes me. I have been here three times and each time has been fantastic. The mix of the rice with the warm crispy nori that you literally see them heat up in front of you is an amazing combo with the delightful melt in your mouth fish. I haven't strayed too far from the fixed sets but have really enjoyed the 4 and 5 piece set. My favorites include the toro, golden ratio hamachi, and blue crab. I would strongly disagree with complaints about value given the quality of the product. It's also a pleasant experience with super cool decor and really nice service.

Nothing special in this restaurant. I am guessing it will remain in soft opening until it eventually closes. Parking situation is terrible in that area to begin with.   I ordered some salmon and hamachi appetizers; they looked like some scrap leftovers when a fish is filleted. Not sure of the taste with that sauce whatever it was.  Menu - not whole lot of choices.  Their \"signature\" offering is the seaweed roll.  Roasted seaweed wrap - really?  Any restaurant can do that!  Only good thing - place is newly renovated.  I don't mind spending money in authentic Japanese restaurant and quality food in the $100 range per diner in restaurants like Ikiru, Sushi Ota in San Diego and Wafu in Oramge County. But in this place - NO!  Don't waste your money here!
It was new dining experience. Never seen anything like this even in Japan! You should go, experience it yourself. Taste? Of course very good. This is a total package! Myungja

Really good food in a fun unique atmosphere. Some of the mixtures of fish and sauce like mayo n scallops were more 4 star but that was when they opened so probably have tightened up since. Its fun to go here. Its a little more $ than other places but worth the extra cost.
Sushi was supah good and yumm,, and the sushi maker / waitress were friendly, kind and personal. Love this place, and will come back. The sake is good 2!

First timer with a party of 3 and it was a great experience. Very solid hand rolls, especially the blue crab. Very cool artwork on the sides on the restaurant. I enjoyed talking to the chefs at work as they prep fresh fish in front of you.

One of the best Temaki bars I've been to. The chefs actually talk to you to have a conversation which is always a plus. I mean, that's sorta why you go up to the bar seat, to have a more intimate time between your food and how it's made. My top faves were the negi salmon and the blue crab. V fresh on ya mommas! I can't help it drool while I'm writing this. If you like the poke shop next door, I'm sure you'll love this!

Had to give this place a try since I'm a sucker for handrolls. First impression, the place is kinda small with a U-shaped bar that sits around 20 people. It allows the chefs to interact with their customers which makes the experience much more interesting. The handroll is served 1 at a time directly to your hand to ensure freshness. The rolls are simple yet full of flavor - crispy seaweed wrap, well seasoned rice, good quality fish and a hint of a herb or other flavor depends on the roll.  I got the SAN combo with uni and unagi added.  All of them were really good. My favorite would be the blue crab and uni. They both have a very rich and delicate flavor. I totally recommend this place to anyone who appreciates a delicate yet satisfying Japanese flavor.

I went here during their soft opening special. So this is a late post. Service was good. I ordered the set for the sushi hand rolls. Each roll was made as you finished each roll. They tried to pay attention to each customer so that each roll is made fresh. It is pricier than expected with fresh made hand rolls.
With the toasted seaweed wraps served warm, one at a time, this place has the best sushi rolls I've tasted in town. Simple and delicious.

I had I high hopes for this place considering everything junya watanabe touches turns to gold but I was a bit disapointed. The food itself is quite good: everything from the rice to the nori and soy sauce was extremely high quality. The wasabi was also freshly grated and they offer an endless supply of ginger. My biggest gripe is their pricing and portion size. Each handroll was about a three biter and you can get five of those for 21 dollars. They had a two for one special that made it more affordable but honestly this is not the place to go for a satisfying lunch or dinner. I understand how high quality food comes at a price but considering the location and clientale this did not seem like a splurge worthy place. Nonetheless the food was great and if I was swimming in cash I would come here often.

This place is awesome. Perfect date setting or a nice time with friends and family.  The rolls were fresh delicious and the beer and sake are phenomenal. Chef James is unbelievably observant and meticulous in his preparation and presentation of the rolls. The service was awesome, Hana was a great server and we always had everything we needed. Five stars! Really great experience.

This little concept is fire. Hand rolls, apps and incredible service. Part of the raki raki restaurant family, the food quality is exquisite.
