I'm not often a yelp reviewer, yet this place has the sauce. I went maine lobby, blue crab, ikura, spanish mackerel app, negi yellowtail, bay scallop, wagyu, and yellowtail sashimi. Double down on the spanish mack. It's the mackD. Ask for it if you're a foodie. It's not on the menu.

Very cool place . Went for lunch and surprised it wasn't busy consider the shopping center it shares with Raki Raki is a zoo. This is a hand roll place . I got 5 hand roll deal and very good price and filling . Each handroll was a decent size . I liked all the fish they offered very fish and good. The chef is friendly and makes it right there in front of you . I'll be back .
Pretty bad ass and unique spin on sushi.  Small hand rolls that are 4 good bites with recommended menus to get a flavor for everything.

Huge fan of this place! The staff is great and the food is phenomenal. The GO [5] Temaki is my go to. 5 handrolls for just over $20, and you get lobster- can't beat it! The only downfall is parking. This lot has an abundance of great foodie spots so parking in the lot does get tight. Make sure to give yourself ample amounts of time to park and try street parking!
It's the only hand roll place in town, and they don't disappoint with their fresh fish options. They have limited seats, so make sure you come early as they don't take reservations.

I was excited to hear about the opening of this sushi bar since I'm an avid fan of Kazunori in LA (and even the short-lived Kazunori knock-off Kiyomizu in Santa Ana).   The decor and setup of J Wata is just like Kazunori and Kiyomizu. The menu here, however, is more extensive and creative, which is both a hit and a miss. I love the idea of having more variety on the menu, but I found that the toppings and the seasoning were overdone. I could barely taste the fish in the handroll due to heavy-handed seasoning, and the fish didn't taste as fresh or flavorful as Kazunori. Furthermore, the handrolls are smaller here and more expensive. It was nice though to try different types of fish and other side dishes that aren't served at Kazunori. I do like the toasted nori here over the regular nori at Kazunori.  I don't understand their ginger and wasabi. The ginger was super salty and didn't taste good. The wasabi had zero hotness and was kind of gritty/chunky.   Based on the price, I would not eat here again unless there is a special. I would rather eat at cheaper sushi roll places. For the simplicity of a fresh handroll, I will still go to LA for Kazunori.

If it wasn't for the bogo deal I don't think it's worth the money. I waited for about an hr to get seating for two. It took some time to get our rolls. It would be nice if they have more chefs to tend to maybe one or two parties at a time. Average cost for a roll is about 4-7 dollars. I thought that was pretty pricey. These are not your typical hand rolls either. They are pretty small which you can finish with three bites. We each got a set with 5 rolls. We were still pretty hungry walking out. Happy lemon was such a nice treat and it is right across the street.
Small and quaint. Excellent service and food. Love the father/son team. Perfect place for a casual date or to bring a teenage kid. I wouldn't recommend for little kids.

Very simple ingredients with unbelievable flavors! The chef personally hands you each roll and is ready to answer any questions. The golden ratio is my favorite, would order 10 of those because they are just crazy good!

I AM A HUGE FAN OF HANDROLLS, and this place does an amazing job. I love the seating arrangement, a U shape bar. The staff here are all attentive and make sure you are enjoying your time there. I think its because of the limited seating that they are able to really put in the attention. The menu is done a la carte or by a set. The sets are definitely better for pricing. My bf and I both got the 5 handrolls  and we both really enjoyed each one. Make sure to eat the handroll immediately when they hand it to you so that the seaweed stays crispy. Toasted, crispy seaweed is what stands out for me when it comes to these handrolls. I adore the crab and lobster ones. If I had to pick one, crab all the way.

Amazing experience! The hand roll experience is unlike anything else in San Diego. The attention to detail in each hand roll is spot on. I would recommend trying one of their set menu. My favorite is the blue crab roll (melt in your mouth worthy). Servers are very attentive and friendly. I already can't wait to come back!
Had a great meal here. We selected the top tier omakase selection and were not disappointed. Top quality ingredients and the was very accommodating.

We had a fantastic experience fantastic meal and incredibly good service today. You have to be into these wonderful sushi rolls to make sure you're fine with a somewhat limited menu but with super high-quality products and all the components including the toasted Nori. Staff were friendly the service is excellent and this new restaurant is highly recommended.

Excellent hand rollls.  Warm crispy seaweed wrapping cold sushi and room temp rice inside.   First few visits service was a little variable.  It is tricky because they make them right in front of you and give them right to you so they are absolutely fresh.  Last time the place was full.  And the service was excellent.  Kirin on tap.  Unique seasoning.   Unique experience.

SUPER nice people/ great service! GREAT food  yum yum  the sushi chefs are VERY skilled and super nice. I highly recommend the hamachi golden-ratio taro roll it has delicious yellowtail fish and the veggies in it give it a nice crunch. If you are in the mood for spice, get the spicy tuna roll! The flavors are amazing  anyways this place was the best sushi I've had in a LONG time

Great place. Not fancy but very good temaki. Hope it lasts - I'm not sure the location is right for semi-pricey 'plain' temaki. Boy is the fish fresh. And the roasted nori... We'll be back, but one does tend to keep ordering so it can get pricey. Fantastic sake too. Support it!

First time here, the quality of fish is so good! Moderately priced for what it is, I'm very happy with it. It's not the greatest for when you're insanely hungry, but the taste is outta this world! The yellowtail, bluefin crab and the salmon were my favorites!

Checked this place out while visiting SD. The food was okay, not bad, not good, just ok. Service was amazing. Will I return? Probably not, only because I didn't walk away being wow'ed, nor do I think I'll crave it again.

Unbelievable food! Unbelievably good flavor and the ambience couldn't be more amazing. The GO FIVE Rolls are made hand fresh right in front of your eyes. Bar none best rolls ever had in my life. Fresh ginger fresh wasabi like it was flown in 5 minutes ago!!!!

This place is amazing. From the super talented chefs to the super friendly staff, the entire place earns its 5 stars! Come for the ambiance but stay for the food. The Spicy Tuna hand roll blew my mind and miso soup kicks some serious ass. Do your self a favor and stop by J Wata for some delicious food.

Of my two visits J Wata has quickly become my favorite Japanese restaurant in San Diego. When first entering you are immediately drawn to the hip murals wrapped around the walls. The menu is very simple and to the point. You can either order individual rolls or get a pre set option. I have tried the spicy salmon, unagi, spicy toro, Maine lobster, negi yellowtail, blue crab, and the negi salmon. All of them were amazing with the unagi and spicy salmon being my favorites. The unagi has a perfect amount of bbq flavor without it being an overkill. I loved the creamy texture of the spicy toro and how well the rice complements the fish. Service is awesome, they definitely aim to make everyone have a personalized experience. The chef James is very knowledgeable about the menu as well as being great to talk to! The quality and the experience you get doesn't compare to anywhere else in San Diego.

Love this!! FINALLY a warm sushi handroll place in San Diego. This place comes really close to Kazu Nori in Los Angeles. For a soft opening,  the service was great and food on point.  The blue crab and wagyu beef were a hit with the kids. The price was fair for the quality of ingredients. Will definitely return!

Fresh ingredients and great customer service. I've worked in over 6 sushi restaurants so I'm picky when it comes to sushi. I went during the buy 1 get 1 with the set menu so that was totally worth it! But it's really expensive for really small, thin hand rolls so I won't be coming back unless they have a promo again. :(

Pretty decent. But missing one star due to not particularly special tastes from some maki and sashimi on their menu. Their Sashimi is soaked in ponzu. Too much sauce it loses the original taste. Don't like to put good fish marinated in a cheap  sauce. Blue crab and Main lobster makis are 5 stars. All the other you can taste them at other sushi places. For that reason I give 4 Star. But blue crab and main lobster were awesome. ! Yeah I'm rather picky eater.

This temaki bar is a wonderful addition to Convoy St!   I'm in complete disagreement with (and annoyed by) the reviews saying the food here is bland. Good hand rolls are fresh, simplistic, and let the ingredients speak for themselves. If you want a specialty roll slathered in sauce or whatever to mask the taste of your fish, it's true that this place isn't for you... but neither is good sushi. Enjoy that crap elsewhere and stop writing bad reviews for restaurants that serve food you already know going in isn't going to be your \"thing.\"    And yes, shellfish is mixed with mayo (blue crab and lobster), and these rolls are delicious. The lobster is reminiscent of a New England lobster roll but wrapped in rice and seaweed rather than bread. Shellfish + mayo is a classic pairing. If it isn't your \"thing,\" don't order those items and stick to fish only. The more traditional fish is served as typical with rice and vinegar.  We have been here multiple times since the grand opening and the food is consistently good. Prices are very reasonable and the hand roll chefs are always friendly and fast in service. I really do hope they stick around!

Chef Alex is awesome! The temaki bar creates a buzz in the dining room because it is hands on! The whole restaurant has a great energy and aesthetic. The concept is simple and perfectly executed: simple fresh ingredients and face-time with the chef. We trusted Alex to choose for us since it was our first time in and it worked out perfectly, four tasty Temaki and then one more \"premium temaki\" which was custardy uni on a fresh mint leaf. Perfect way to end a light and thoroughly satisfying meal. When we got the bill we were pleasantly surprised with the price, seems like they have options for any diner. I think they are onto something very trendy and and it must be exciting to be on the ground floor (the restaurant is about four months old). Lots of potential here, excited to see this place grow.

This place should have 5 stars. Very simple and perfectly executed hand roll bar. It made me feel so relaxed just sitting there. James was our chef and very attentive and informative as well as the rest of the staff!
Incredibly good temaki rolls, great quick service, super friendly staff! The food is delicious and fresh and reasonably priced. Highly recommend this place!

We stumbled across this place since two other nearby locations had a wait time of over two hours. This place was amazing!!! The toasted seaweed was amazing. Everything was super high quality and staff was pleasant. Already planning on coming back with friends.

I think the Raki family is trying to take over this overcrowded, terribly awful parking strip mall. This is a novel new Temaki Bar essentially perfecting sushi hand rolls. The seaweed nori is toasted and crisp for each roll. Quality of ingredients is very good so far on opening. Prices can add up quickly - e.g the lobster roll costs ~ $7.50 and can be finished in 2-3 man bites - you'll end up nibbling them to make the rolls go farther.   Most of the rolls are $5-6 or so. The set menus are a little better. Good food but don't go hungry. An upgrade from Raki - never very impressed by them but they do pack 'em in.

If I had to describe my dining experience in three words: artistic, fresh, and addictive.   Artistic: You're seated at the bar overlooking the masterful chefs as they prepare each roll to order. Their craft and dedication to quality work are mesmerizing- the way they wave the nori over an open flame, the way they shape the freshly cooked rice, the way they cook the indulgently fatty wagyu shabu meat, I could go on. You've got a front row seat to watch this beautiful dance.  Fresh: There's never been a more appropriate place to eat with your hands. You select your meal set (ranging from 3-5 rolls each), then the chef prepares each roll by hand before you. Your chef hands you the rolls and they encourage you to receive each roll by hand (instead of letting them place it on your plate), this way you can immediately begin eating it. From the start, they emphasized the urgency of eating the rolls immediately in order to preserve the integrity for the ingredients. Each roll uses super high quality ingredients- the fish is light and pure, the rice is warm and flavorful, and the nori is toasty and crisp. If you're anything like me, I've been taught to always wait for everyone to receive their food before eating, so it was a bit weird to start eating before my friends got their rolls, but again, you have to eat the rolls while they're fresh. And no worries, the chef keeps a watchful eye in order to control the pacing of your meal. They're mindful to provide you with some time between rolls to savor each one, that way you're never overwhelmed or rushed, while also ensuring you're never waiting too long for your next roll.   Addictive: Oh man, my friends and I joked about inquiring how much it'd cost to rent out a seat at the bar and set up permanent residence. But honestly, even before our meal set was over, we were bummed that our dining experience was coming to an end. We're definitely going to be returning soon.  The only con would be parking. It's located in the same plaza as RakiRaki and Pokkirito (same owners); parking has always been challenging in this plaza, but I'm sure with the success of this restaurant, parking will be nearly impossible. Good luck, it's worth the wait.

My girlfriend and I came here at lunch time around 11:30AM and it wasn't very busy which we were happy about. We had the GO combo and wagyu and it was pretty tasty. We both agreed that it was awkward AF every time one of the chefs would walk up to us and hand us a handroll. Why isn't there a small plate on the bar where the chef could place the handroll when its ready? Instead we had to do this awkward exchange with the chef/stranger 5-6 times to eat.

Very glad there is a place like this in San Diego, no more relying on LA trips to get Kazunori. If only the parking situation was a bit better in this area, it'd be a slam dunk. Handrolls were great, and service was even better!  Looking forward to coming back.

I went for dinner with my husband and 2 other friends. The place is small and they make your order one at a time. You sit around the bar next to other people and they are standing in the middle making everyone's order. It's pretty interesting and fun. It is an actual Temaki Bar no other sits or tables. Which makes it unique

What an awesome restaurant and dining concept! Had an amazing experience here a few nights ago... great ambiance, the food was excellent, and our chef Alex was so kind and knowledgeable! Every hand roll was perfectly crafted and absolutely delicious- the prices were extremely affordable for the quality of the food. The wait staff were extremely attentive and friendly. I will definitely be dining here again!

Tasty but expensive for what it is. This place is basically sugar fish from Los Angeles but mostly focused on hand rolls. While tasty the prices are kind of not worth it for the food you get. We spent $50 and felt like we wanted a ramen next door. Still I might go back if I wanted a light fresh meal.

It's solid. However, I don't think it was mind blowingly good for the price that you pay. My brother definitely left still hungry, so we went to another store to grab more food.  The chef was very nice though!

Happy there's a Hand Roll restaurant in San Diego! This one is definitely worth the try.  Food: I got the \"Go\" set which is the most expensive, in order of favorite to least favorite, Lobster, Scallop (and I generally dislike scallop), Spicy Tuna, Blue Crab, and Salmon. There were shells in my Blue Crab roll... bummer. I was really excited for Salmon but it was pretty bland. I wish they brushed it with some soy sauce/wasabi at least. I wish the rice was a teensy bit warmer.   Atmosphere: I think they were trying to go for a hip ambience? I didn't really care for the music.   Service: Really nice and attentive service!   I would come back: big IF... I was feeling spendy and wanted something fancy, quick, and fresh

Amazing hand rolls only second to their exceptional customer service. I went on a weekday at 11:45am trying to beat the lunch rush and was surprised to find the place semi empty. If you're near the Convoy area, do not skip out on this new hand-roll bar. We were well attended and the sushi chef worked his magic to make sure each roll was delivered timely. Would absolutely recommend and can't wait to come back.
This place has a neat concept and the food was fresh and delicious! We recommend trying it out.  There aren't any other places like it that we know of!  Great business model too.

I came during the grand opening weekend with a BOGO deal (two sets for the price of one). With the BOGO deal, I do think the price is worth it. However, if I were paying the regular price, this place would be a poor value, especially considering that I wasn't full even after 5 rolls. While the concept and setting is cool, overall the quality of the ingredients is not much better than that used at Pokerrito a couple doors down (given the fact that they are owned by the same owner, I wouldn't be surprised if they used the same exact ingredients). In fact, none of the ingredients are freshly prepared; they are all scooped out of tins you would find at Chipotle and then are assembled like a burrito. At the end of the day, you're paying $22 (before tax + tip) for 5 tiny handrolls when you can walk 20 feet over to Pokerrito and experience 1 humongous handroll (aka sushi burrito) made with the same exact ingredients for less than half the price (with no tip). Or, you could go to a real sushi restaurant and pay the same price for a real sushi chef to prepare handrolls for you with better and fresher ingredients. If they lowered the price by 25% or improved the quality of their ingredients, I would consider going again but at the moment, you're certainly overpaying for what you get.  Taste: 2.5/5 Value: 1/5 Experience: 3.5/5

This is quite the experience. It tastes delicious and it's such a nice change from all the sushi places that make crazy rolls with sub par ingredients. The hand rolls are simple yet so delicious. I would come here every day if my wallet allowed.   This place is going to get busy once people start hearing about it so go now and get it while you can. Hopefully it doesn't go down in quality once it gains popularity. And I swear if you complain about slow service maybe you shouldn't come here. The serving of the rolls is very personalized and the serving is spaced out so you can enjoy your food.   Right now they really seem to care about honing their craft and making sure everything is perfect.
The food was ok ..... super expensive not very satisfying.. I wouldn't go back. One small roll for over $5.. service was good
One of the best bites of raw fish I've ever had. The negitoro was unbelievable. Amazing quiet date night spot.

This place recently opened and I gotta say, the rolls were great and really fresh. You can taste the quality of the ingredients used. The staff was also attentive, coming just frequent enough to ask if we want more water or ginger. James was our chef and he was very friendly and inviting. I recommend anyone who enjoys hand rolls and sashimi to try this place out!!

Came here out of the blue with my friend because the revolving sushi place had too long of a wait. We both actually ended up liking this place much better. The experience is cool and the food tastes authentic and good!

YES. Finally a hand roll sushi concept in San Diego. This place is amazing. There was no wait during the soft opening, but I'd expect crowds to flock here as people learn about this place. The negi toro and spicy salmon are my favorite.

I rarely give 5 stars but this place deserves it. Simple menu, good service, incredibly fresh and  great tasting  hand rolls. The chef hands the freshly made rolls to be eaten immediately. The toasted nori adds perfect texture. Good value for the money. If there is a downside, it is the availability of parking.

First time at J Wata and it was delicious! The hamachi sashimi had a nice clean refreshing finish to it, and the hand rolls were perfect balance of rice to fish and so good! The chef kept a nice pace as he carefully prepared the next roll after I was done with each roll, to ensure quality and integrity of the roll. Can't wait to go back on my next SD visit!

Brand new Restaurant. They are all about the hand roll. Nori is like no other I have tasted and they give you one roll at a time. They want you to experience each roll as it is crispy and fresh and not soggy. The chefs are very nice and the owner came by to talk to us. He owns Raki Raki and Pokerito and is very personable and friendly. He seems to care about producing a quality product. Tried the Ikura (Salmon Roe) and was one of the freshest I have ever had. I actually judge my opinion of the Restaurant with the quality of their Ikura. My husband loved it and he is not normally a fan. Great place to try. We will return.

If you are looking for Japanese food, this is not the place for you.  While the food was good, it was pre-prepared seafood, meaning the seafood contents are premixed with a tasty sauce.  Not traditional by any means.  if looking for sushi, go elsewhere.  The place seemed clean and nice.  we had the spicy salmon, blue crab and lobster hand rolls.  We were expecting something freshly prepared.  They were all pre-mixed fillings.

J Wata Temaki Bar is an experience of its own. It brings the intimate experience of Japanese culture cuisine to Convoy. It definitely isn't a place to go if you plan to stuff yourself but the food is definitely quality. My favorite hand rolls were the scallops and yellowtail. In addition to those I also order the wagyu which was delicious as well. Would definitely recommend this place!!

So, I was waiting to go to this new place since they opened the restaurant. I received an email with a special invitation and then I decided to check it out. I got there at 7pm and it was alright to get two seats. We ordered and omg it took forever to start receiving the hand rolls. Our server forgot our water and we needed to keep asking for it . We ran out of soy sauce and we asked her for more, we ended up asking for the couple seating close to us if we could  have some of their soy sauce. We left the restaurant almost 9:30/10pm. The bill was pretty expensive for little hand rolls. Anyway I had the discount but guess what?!  I just realized the same server who was serving us didn't give me the discount. I was so upset that I didn't wanna come back there. In a nutshell I won't come back there. I hope you all have better experience than me.

Great service, cool place and the food was good but the rolls are small.  Not a 5 star because of the size, these are more like appy size.  I did enjoy the food but I will stick with the cone hand rolls as you get twice as much for the same price.
Delicious!!! Definitely our new go to date spot! The servers were friendly and attentive and everything was fresh!

The rice and nori are good and the waitress was cute and friendly. Those are the only good points.  The hamachi hand-roll was mild, the toro was totally flavorless, the spicy salmon was not spicy but at least was decently fresh, and the blue crab was alright. But all of them were really tiny. The price seems cheap but it's really not when you factor in how extremely tiny the amount of fish in each roll is, as well as how mediocre it all was.  Even the hot tea was served in a cup that burned my hand if held for more than a second. And it just tasted like hot water, not tea.
Best hand rolls I've ever had! Such incredibly nice staff and wonderful food, highly recommend.
Dinning innovation! You have to be there to sense it and taste it. You will like it for sure. guaranteed! Enjoy your Temaki! A sushi lover

This place was amazing! I got the go set (includes 5 hand rolls), and the deep fried salmon cheese. I think my favorite was the salmon roll, but honestly everything was great. You can tell all the fish is really fresh too. On top of the food being great, the staff was also very friendly and attentive.

Great food and great service. If your feeling experimental try the wagyu with chopped wasabi and also the Ikura with shiso they marinate it in-house. Super great food and the freshly roasted seaweed takes it over the top.

Let me start by saying, you need to Lyft or Uber here. Don't even try to mess with this parking situation, especially not on a weekend. Also, make a reservation, even if it's just two of you. It's all bar seating so it fills up quick. This is a small venue, in a busy complex, be prepared for a crowd. Now that all of that is out of the way, we get to the important stuff. The food. This is the best sushi I have ever had. I am not joking. This is NOT a \"California roll\" type joint. The \"rolls\" are more like non-cone hand rolls, focused on the one main ingredient. You are served them one by one, you watch the chef toast the seaweed, delicately add your main ingredient, \u0026 hand it to you (his hand to yours). You are not going to some generic \"sushi\" restaurant. You are about to have the highest quality seaweed, the best rice, the freshest most delicious fish, and everything is made in front of you. I recommend that you start with some sashimi appetizers, (the Yellowtail is my favorite). Also, the miso soup is incredible and if you order one of the prefix combos of rolls, it is included. Each person plan on get 3-5 rolls after appetizers if you're hungry \u0026 you can easily add more if you're hungry by the end. Everything is so fresh, including their wasabi \u0026 ginger. They even have I think 4 veggie rolls! Please go here, they put so much detail into making this place as great as it is. The wall art and lighting fixture above the bar, the warm staff, (SHOUT OUT TO JAMES!!!) everything about this place is incredible. Do not sleep on this. I promise you, best sushi experience in San Diego.

I wanted to thank Chef Brian for the great service and made our dining experience as wonderful as it could be. Server Vincent with the great smile and didn't stop me from my #sundayfunday drinking. The host, I never got your name but I know you tried your best to help me understand the concept of the restaurant. That being said, we also went for the #grandopening event BOGOF #stealdeal. Of course, we went for the baller status and got the GO set. We really enjoyed the Maine \u0026 Blue Crab Temaki. They are served with a house creamy sauce. Best Spicy Tuna I ever had and it wasn't that crazy neon red color. Here is couple #freetips: Pass on the Wagyu Shabu. It was tender but bland. End your Temaki experience with Unagi. They boil it and torch it up and it is a just prefect way to end your meal. Try the white wine. Want to know a secret menu item? If you come an hour before they close, ask for the Brian's special. They can serve you the Shabu broth that has been simmering all day with Wagyu Beef. #extraprotein. You are welcome, friends. :)

We spent $50+ at this place and left so hungry we had to find another spot in Convoy to eat at.  The food is decent - fish quality is similar to what you'd find at Poke bowl places (sashimi is not cut on the spot, but stored in Tupperware containers Subway style).  The idea of being served handmade temaki rolls from a chef at a bar is a pretty cool experience,  but then again you have to wait for the chef to cook one hand roll at a time for everyone seated at the bar - not a good idea when you're hungry! Overall the portions are too small and the quality is mediocre at best.  Maybe a good appetizer spot but not if you're looking for a good meal at a good price!
Went because the Kazunori in la is pretty dope. Same concept but falls short. Service was much slower than expected with subpar fish.
I go to Kazu Nori in LA all the time (amazing) but could never find anything comparable in SD... until NOW! Best quality fish (not fishy) and just so tasty. My favorite sushi in SD hands down!!!

I timed two recent visits for a time between lunchtime and dinner to avoid crowds and it paid off, immediate seating excellent service. The food was awesome, could taste the freshness of the various fish and seafood. The hot green tea is excellent as well. The staff are professional and skilled.  The cool decor and music add to the experience.
4.5 great fresh fish, they bring the rolls pretty fast, the temaki are really tasty, what this place has is freshness!!!!
This is probably one of my new favorite spots in Convoy. No other place can touch their customer service. Plus, they have cute modern decor which makes you feel really comfortable.
Fantastic experience here. Delightfully Unique. Good date spot or if you're just looking for something trendy and new. Lobster Temaki was my favorite, but everything was good.
Crispy hand rolls.  Cool combos, although I went for a la carts to have the wagyu and other specialty items. Did I mention crispy hand rolls.

Bruh I don't know why these people in here writing fake reviews. Let me be straight with you, none of the people who wrote reviews probably have never been to a real sushi place. If you want real sushi, idk just don't go here. I ordered a sushi roll expecting a WHOLE SUSHI ROLL, but instead I got a cigar sized one that I finished in two bites. They have only have one guy working the sushi bar and everyone awkwardly sits across each other waiting for their sushi to be handed to them, yes, handed to them. Not on a plate, but straight up \"here's your sushi...\" If I'm going to spend roughly $16.45 on 4 rolls, I expect quality, hand-made (as advertised), full-sized rolls. If you see anyone walk in there, it's either their first time there or they have exhausted ALL other options in ALL the restaurants in Convoy. Please save your money, spare your wallet the pain, and stay home and make your own sushi.

Stumbled into this place while waiting for Ramen next door. Opened by the same chef as Rakiraki. The hand rolls were divine. The blue crab roll was our favorite. The service was exceptional and the sushi chefs were very personable.

this place is so good. like REALLY good, like we ate 20 hand rolls + two plates of sashimi good. the experience is intimate and close with the chef, you can watch them prepare the orders right there as they're talking to you. the fish is soooo fresh and soft and delicious. no joke the best salmon sashimi i've ever had it wasn't fishy at all and was incredibly smooth. the hand rolls were perfect sized amounts and incredible delights of heaven into little sushi. thank you chef James for the amazing experience!!
